into the road iknd he listened closely to the motor a it turned over listened for knock the road spread dimly under the weak light of the car chapter seventeen t he car of the migrant people crawled out of the side road onto the great cross country highway and they took the migrant way to the west in the day light they scuttled like bug to the westward and a the dark caught them they clustered like bug near to shelter and to water and because they were lonely and perplexed because they had all come from a place of sadness and worry and defeat and because they were all going to a new mysterious place they huddled together they talked together they shared their life their food and the thing they hoped for in the new country thus it might be that one family camped near a spring and another camped for the spring and for company and a third because two family had pioneered the place and found it good and when the sun went down per hap twenty family and twenty car were there in the evening a strange thing happened the twenty fami lie became one family the child were the child of all the loss of home became one loss and the golden time in the west wa one dream and it might be that a sick child threw despair into the heart of twenty family of a hundred peo ple that a birth there in a tent kept a hundred people quiet and awestruck through the night and filled a hundred people with the birth joy in the morning a family which the night defore had been lost and fearful might search it good to find a present for a new baby in the evening sitting about the grape of wrath the fire the twenty were one they grew to be unit of the camp unit of the evening and the night a guitar un wrapped from a blanket and tuned and the song which were all of the people were sung in the night men sang the word and woman hummed the tune every night a world created complete with furniture friend made and enemy established a world complete with braggart and with coward with quiet men with humble men with kindly men every night relationship that make a world established and every morning the world torn down like a circus at first the family were timid in the building and tum bling world but gradually the technique of building world became their technique then leader emerged then law were made then code came into being and a the world moved westward they were more complete and better fur nished for their builder were more experienced in building them the family learned what right must be observed the right of privacy in the tent the right to keep the past black hidden in the heart the right to talk and to listen the right to refuse help or to accept to offer help or to decline it the right of son to court and daughter to be courted the right of the hungry to be fed the right of the pregnant and the sick to transcend all other right and the family learned although no one told them what right are monstrous and must be destroyed the right to intrude upon privacy the right to be noisy while the camp slept the right of seduction or rape the right of adultery and theft and murder these right were crashed because the little world could not exist for even a night with such right alive the grape of wrath and a the world moved westward rule became law although no one told the family it is unlawful to foul near the camp it is unlawful in any way to foul the drinking water it is unlawful to eat good rich food near one who is hungry unless he is asked to share and with the law the punishment and there were only two a quick and murderous fight or ostracism and ostra cism wa the worst for if one broke the law his name and face went with him and he had no place in any world no matter where created in the world social conduct became fixed and rigid so that a man must say good morning when asked for it so that a man might have a willing girl if he stayed with her if he fathered her child and protected them but a man might not have one girl one night and another the next for this would endanger the world the family moved westward and the technique of build ing the world improved so that the people could be safe in their world and the form wa so fixed that a family acting in the rule knew it wa safe in the rule there grew up government in the world with leader with elder a man who wa wise found that his wisdom wa needed in every camp a man who wa a fool could not change his folly with his world and a kind of insurance de veloped in these night a man with food fed a hungry man and thus insured himself against hunger and when a baby died a pile of silver coin grew at the door flap for a baby must be well buried since it ha had nothing else of life an old man may be left in a potter s field but not a baby a certain physical pattern is needed for the building of a world water a river bank a stream a spring or even a faucet unguarded and there is needed enough flat land to the grape of wrath pitch the tent a little brush or wood to build the fire if there is a garbage dump not too far off all the better for there can be found equipment stove top a curved fender to shelter the fire and can to cook in and to eat from and the world were built in the evening the people moving in from the highway made them with their tent and their heart and their brain in the morning the tent came down the canvas wa folded the tent pole tied along the running board the bed put in place on the car the pot in their place and a the family moved westward the technique of building up a home in the evening and tearing it down with the morning light became fixed so that the folded tent wa packed in one place the cooking pot counted in their box and a the car moved westward each member of the family grew into his proper place grew into his duty so t he migrant people scuttling for work scrabbling to live looked always for pleasure dug for pleasure manufactured pleasure and they were hungry for amusement sometimes amusement lay in speech and they climbed up their life with joke and it came about in the camp along the road on the ditch bank beside the stream under the sycamore that the story teller grew into being so that the people gathered in the low firelight to hear the gifted one and they listened while the tale were told and their participation made the story great wa a recruit against geronimo and the people listened and their quiet eye reflected the dying fire them injun wa cute slick a snake an quiet when they wanted could go through dry leaf an make no rustle try to do that sometimes and the people listened and remembered the crash of dry leaf under their foot come the change of season an the cloud up wrong time ever hear of the army doing anything right give the army ten chance an they ll stumble along took three regiment to kill a hundred brave always and the people listened and their face were quiet with listening the story teller gathering attention into their the grape of wrath tale spoke in great rhythm spoke in great word because the tale were great and the listener became great through them they wa a brave on a ridge against the sun knowed he stood out spread his arm an stood naked a morning an against the sun maybe he wa crazy i don know stood there arm spread out like a cross he looked four hundred yard an the men well they raised their sight an they felt the wind with their finger an then they jus lay there an could n shoot maybe that injun knowed somepin knowed we couldn shoot jes laid there with the rifle cocked an didn even put em to our shoulder lookin at him head band one feather could see it an naked a the sun long time we laid there an looked an he never moved an then the captain got mad shoot you crazy bastard shoot he yell an we jus laid there i ll give you to a five count an then mark you down the captain say well sir we put up our rifle slow an ever man hoped some body d shoot first i ain t never been so sad in my life an i laid my sight on his belly cause you can t stop a injun no other place an then well he jest plunked down an rolled an we went up an he wasn big he d looked so grand up there all tore to piece an little ever see a cock pheasant stiff and beautiful ever feather drawed an painted an even his eye drawed in pretty an bang you pick him up bloody an twisted an you spoiled somepin better n you an eatin him don t never make it up to you cause yon spoiled somepin in yaself an you can t never fix it up and the people nodded and perhaps the fire spurted a little light and showed their eye looking in on themselves against the sun with his arm out an he looked big a god the grape of wrath and perhaps a man balanced twenty cent between food and pleasure and he went to a movie in marysville or tulare in cere or mountain view and he wrath anything with a harmonica thin reedy single tone or chord or melody with rhythm chord you can mold the music with curved hand making it wail and cry like bagpipe making it full and round like an organ making it a sharp and bitter a the reed pipe of the hill and you can play and put it back in your pocket it is always with you always in youi pocket and a you play you learn new trick new way to mold the tone with your hand to pinch the tone with your lip and no one teach you you feel around sometimes alone in the shade at noon sometimes in the tent door after supper when the woman are washing up your foot tap gently on the ground your eyebrow rise and fall in rhythm and if you lose it or break it why it s no great loss you can buy another for a quarter a guitar is more precious must learn this thing finger of the left hand must have callus cap thumb of the right hand a horn of callus stretch the left hand finger stretch them like a spider s leg to get the hard pad on the beautiful in california valley in which i the fruit blossom are fragrant pink and white water jl in a shallow sea then the first tendril of the grape swelling from the old gnarled vine cascade down to cover the trunk the full green hill are round and soft a breast and on the level vegetable land are the mile long row of pale green lettuce and the spindly little cauliflower the gray green unearthly artichoke plant and then the leaf break out on the tree and the petal drop from the fruit tree and carpet the earth with pink and white the center of the blossom swell and grow and color cherry and apple peach and pear fig which close the flower in the fruit all california quickens with produce and the fruit grows heavy and the limb bend gradually under the fruit so that little crutch must be placed under them to support the weight behind the fruitfulness are men of understanding and knowledge and skill men who experiment with seed end lessly developing the technique for greater crop of plant whose root will resist the million enemy of the earth the mold the insect the rust the blight these men work carefully and endlessly to perfect the seed the root and there are the men of chemistry who spray the tree against pest who sulphur the grape who cut out disease and rot the grape of wrath mildew and sickness doctor of preventive medicine men at the border who look for fruit fly for japanese beetle men who quarantine the sick tree and root them out and bum them men of knowledge the men who graft the young tree the little vine are the cleverest of all for theirs is a surgeon s job a tender and delicate and these men must have surgeon hand and surgeon heart to slit the bark to place the graft to bind the wound and cover them from the air these are great men along the row the cultivator move tearing the spring grass and turning it under to make a fertile earth breaking the ground to hold the water up near the surface ridging the ground in little pool for the irrigation destroying the weed root that may drink the water away from the tree and all the time the fruit swell and the flower break out in long cluster on the vine and in the growing year the warmth grows and the leaf turn dark green the prune lengthen like little green bird s egg and the limb sag down against the crutch under the weight and the hard little pear take shape and the beginning of the fuzz come out on the peach grape blossom shed their tiny petal and the nard little bead become green button and the button grow heavy the men who work in the field the owner of the little orchard watch and calculate the year is heavy with produce and men are proud for of their knowledge they can make the year heavy they have transformed the world with their knowledge the short lean wheat ha been made big and productive little sour apple have grown large and sweet and that old grape that grew among the tree and fed the bird it tiny fruit ha mothered a thousand variety red and black green and pale pink purple and yellow and each the grape of wrath variety with it own flavor the men who work in the ex perimental farm have made new fruit nectarine and forty kind of plum walnut with paper the tree and make the seed fertile and big can find no way to let the hun gry people eat their produce men who have created new fruit in the world can not create a system whereby their fruit may be eaten and the failure hang over the state like a great sorrow the work of the root of the vine of the tree must be destroyed to keep up the price and this is the saddest bitter est thing of all carload of orange dumped on the ground the people came for mile to take the fruit but this could not be how would they buy orange at twenty cent a dozen if they could drive out and pick them up and met with hose squirt kerosene on the orange and they are the grape of wrath angry at the crime angry at the people who have come to take the fruit a million people hungry needing the fruit and along the bank to keep the hungry people from fish ing them out slaughter the pig and bury them and let the putrescence drip down into the earth there is a crime here that go beyond denunciation there his baleen the fin back resembles the right whale but is of a less portly girth and a lighter colour approaching to olive his great lip present a cable like aspect formed by the intertwisting slanting part of the back of an angular shape and with a very sharp pointed end even if not the slightest other part of the creature be visible this isolated fin will at time be seen plainly projecting from the surface when the sea is moderately calm and slightly marked with spherical ripple and this gnomon like fin stand up and cast shadow upon the wrinkled surface it may well be supposed that the of these so called whalebone whale there would seem to be several variety most of which however are little known broad nosed whale and beaked whale pike headed whale bunched whale under jawed whale and rostrated whale are the fisherman s name for a few sort in connection with this appellative of whalebone whale it is of great importance to mention that however such a nomenclature may be convenient in facilitating allusion to some kind of whale yet it is in vain to attempt a clear classification of the leviathan founded upon either his baleen or hump or fin or teeth notwithstanding that those marked part or feature very obviously seem better adapted to afford the basis for a regular system of cetology than any other detached bodily distinction which the whale in his kind present how then the baleen hump back fin and teeth these are thing whose peculiarity are indiscriminately dispersed among all sort of whale without any regard to what may be the nature of their structure in other and more essential particular thus the sperm whale and the humpbacked whale each ha a hump but there the similitude cease then this same humpbacked whale and the greenland whale each of these ha baleen but there again the similitude cease and it is just the same with the other part above mentioned in various sort of whale they form such irregular combination or in the case of any one of them detached such an irregular isolation a utterly to defy all general methodization formed upon such a basis on this rock every one of the whale naturalist ha split but it may possibly be conceived that in the internal part of the whale in his anatomy there at least we shall be able to hit the right classification nay what thing for example is there in the greenland whale s anatomy more striking than his baleen yet we have seen that by his baleen it is impossible correctly to classify the greenland whale and if you descend into the bowel of the various leviathan why there you will not find distinction a fiftieth part a available to the systematizer a those external one already enumerated what then remains nothing but to take hold of the whale bodily in their entire liberal volume and boldly sort them that way and this is the bibliographical system here adopted and it is the only one that can possibly succeed for it alone is practicable to proceed book i folio chapter iv hump back me from ever completing anything this whole book is but a draught nay but the draught of a draught oh time strength cash and patience chapter the specksnyder concerning the officer of the whale craft this seems a good a place a any to set down a little domestic peculiarity on ship board arising from the existence of the harpooneer class of officer a class unknown of course in any other marine than the whale fleet the large importance attached to the harpooneer s vocation is evinced by the fact that originally in the old dutch fishery two century and more ago the command of a whale ship wa not wholly lodged in the person now called the captain but wa divided between him and an officer called the specksnyder literally this word mean fat cutter usage however in time made it equivalent to chief harpooneer in those day the captain s authority wa restricted to the navigation and general management of the vessel while over the whale hunting department and all it concern the specksnyder or chief harpooneer reigned supreme in the british greenland fishery under the corrupted title of specksioneer this old dutch official is still retained but his former dignity is sadly abridged at present he rank simply a senior harpooneer and a such is but one of the captain s more inferior subaltern nevertheless a upon the good conduct of the harpooneer the success of a whaling voyage largely depends and since in the american fishery he is not only an important officer in the boat but under certain circumstance night watch on a whaling ground the command of the ship s deck is also his therefore the grand political maxim of the sea demand that he should nominally live apart from the men before the mast and be in some way distinguished a their professional superior though always by them familiarly regarded a their social equal now the grand distinction drawn between officer and man at sea is this the first life aft the last forward hence in whale ship and merchantman alike the mate have their quarter with the captain and so too in most of the american whaler the harpooneer are lodged in the after part of the ship that is to say they take their meal in the captain s cabin and sleep in a place indirectly communicating with it though the long period of a southern whaling voyage by far the longest of all voyage now or ever made by man the peculiar peril of it and the community of interest prevailing among a company all of whom high or low depend for their profit not upon fixed wage but upon their common luck together with their common vigilance intrepidity and hard work though all these thing do in some case tend to beget a less rigorous discipline than in merchantman generally yet never mind how much like an old mesopotamian family these whalemen may in some primitive instance live together for all that the punctilious external at least of the quarter deck are seldom materially relaxed and in no instance done away indeed many are the nantucket ship in which you will see the skipper parading his quarter deck with an elated grandeur not surpassed in any military navy nay extorting almost a much outward homage a if he wore the imperial purple and not the shabbiest of pilot cloth and though of all men the moody captain of the pequod wa the least given to that sort of shallowest assumption and though the only homage he ever exacted wa implicit instantaneous obedience though he required no man to remove the shoe from his foot ere stepping upon the quarter deck and though there were time when owing to peculiar circumstance connected with event hereafter to be detailed he addressed them in unusual term whether of condescension or in terrorem or otherwise yet even captain ahab wa by no mean unobservant of the paramount form and usage of the sea nor perhaps will it fail to be eventually perceived that behind those form and usage a it were he sometimes masked himself incidentally making use of them for other and more private end than they were legitimately intended to subserve that certain sultanism of his brain which had otherwise in a good degree remained unmanifested through those form that same sultanism became incarnate in an irresistible dictatorship for be a man s intellectual superiority what it will it can never assume the practical available supremacy over other men without the aid of some sort of external art and entrenchment always in themselves more or less paltry and base this it is that for ever keep god s true prince of the empire from the world s hustings and leaf the highest honor that this air can give to those men who become famous more through their infinite inferiority to the choice hidden handful of the divine inert than through their undoubted superiority over the dead level of the mass such large virtue lurks in these small thing when extreme political superstition invest them that in some royal instance even to idiot imbecility they have imparted potency but when a in the case of nicholas the czar the ringed crown of geographical empire encircles an imperial brain then the plebeian herd crouch abased before the tremendous centralization nor will the tragic dramatist who would depict mortal indomitableness in it fullest sweep and direct swing ever forget a hint incidentally so important in his art a the one now alluded to but ahab my captain still move before me in all his nantucket grimness and shagginess and in this episode touching emperor and king i must not conceal that i have only to do with a poor old whale hunter like him and therefore all outward majestical trapping and housing are denied me oh ahab what shall be grand in thee it must need be plucked at from the sky and dived for in the deep and featured in the unbodied air chapter the cabin table it is and interesting one let u in some measure expatiate here i take it that the earliest stander of mast head were the old egyptian because in all my research i find none prior to them for though their progenitor the builder of babel must doubtless by their tower have intended to rear the loftiest mast head in all asia or africa either yet ere the final truck wa put to it a that great stone mast of theirs may be said to have gone by the board in the dread gale of god s wrath therefore we can not give these babel builder priority over the egyptian and that the egyptian were a nation of mast head stander is an assertion based upon the general belief among arch ologists that the first pyramid were founded for astronomical purpose a theory singularly supported by the peculiar stair like formation of all four side of those edifice whereby with prodigious long uplifting of their leg those old astronomer were wont to mount to the apex and sing out for new star even a the look out of a modern ship sing out for a sail or a whale just bearing in sight in saint stylite the famous christian hermit of old time who built him a lofty stone pillar in the desert and spent the whole latter portion of his life on it summit hoisting his food from the ground with a tackle in him we have a remarkable instance of a dauntless stander of mast head who wa not to be driven from his place by fog or frost rain hail or sleet but valiantly facing everything out to the last literally died at his post of modern stander of mast head we have but a lifeless set mere stone iron and bronze men who though well capable of facing out a stiff gale are still entirely incompetent to the business of singing out upon discovering any strange sight there is napoleon who upon the top of the column of vendome stand with arm folded some one hundred and fifty foot in the air careless now who rule the deck below whether louis philippe louis blanc or louis the devil great washington too stand high washington nor napoleon nor nelson will answer a single hail from below however madly invoked to befriend by their counsel the distracted deck upon which they gaze however it may be surmised that their spirit penetrate through the thick haze of the future and descry what shoal and what rock must be shunned it may seem unwarrantable to couple in any respect the mast head stander of the land but this custom ha now become obsolete turn we then to the one proper mast head that of a whale ship at sea the three mast head are kept manned from sun rise to sun set the seaman taking their regular turn a at the helm and relieving each other every two hour in the serene weather of the tropic it is exceedingly pleasant the mast head nay to a dreamy meditative man it is delightful there you stand a hundred foot above the silent deck striding along the deep a if the mast were gigantic stilt while beneath you and between your leg a it were swim the hugest monster of the sea even a ship once sailed between the boot of the famous colossus at old rhodes there you stand lost in the infinite series of the sea with nothing ruffled but the wave the tranced ship indolently roll the drowsy trade wind blow everything resolve you into languor for the most part in this tropic whaling life a sublime uneventfulness invests you you hear no news read no gazette extra with startling account of commonplace never delude you into unnecessary excitement you hear of no domestic affliction bankrupt security fall of stock are never troubled with the thought of what you shall have for dinner for all your meal for three year and more are snugly stowed in cask and your bill of fare is immutable in one of those southern whalesmen on a long three or four year voyage a often happens the sum of the various hour you spend at the mast head would amount to several entire month and it is much to be deplored that the place to which you devote so considerable a portion of the whole term of your natural life should be so sadly destitute of anything approaching to a cosy inhabitiveness or adapted to breed a comfortable localness of feeling such a pertains to a bed a hammock a hearse a sentry two thin parallel stick almost peculiar to whalemen called the t gallant cross tree here tossed about by the sea the beginner feel about a cosy a he would standing on a bull s horn to be sure in cold it fleshy tabernacle and can not freely move about in it nor even move out of it without running great risk of perishing like an ignorant pilgrim crossing the snowy alp in winter so a watch coat is not so much of a house a it is a mere envelope or additional skin encasing you you can not put a shelf or chest of drawer in your body and no more can you make a convenient closet of your watch coat it wa the whiteness of the whale that above all thing appalled me but how can i hope to explain myself here and yet in some dim random way explain myself i must else all these chapter might be naught though in many natural object whiteness refiningly enhances beauty a if imparting some special virtue of it own a in marble japonica and pearl and though various nation have in some way recognised a certain royal preeminence in this hue even the barbaric grand old king of pegu placing the title lord of the white elephant above all their other magniloquent ascription of dominion and the modern king of siam unfurling the same snow white quadruped in the royal standard and the hanoverian flag bearing the one figure of a snow white charger and the great austrian empire c sarian heir to overlording rome having for the imperial colour the same imperial hue and though this pre eminence in it applies to the human race itself giving the white man ideal mastership over every dusky tribe and though besides all this whiteness ha been even made significant of gladness for among the roman a white stone marked a joyful day and though in other mortal sympathy and symbolizing this same hue is made the emblem of many touching noble thing the innocence of bride the benignity of age though among the red men of america the giving of the white belt of wampum wa the deepest pledge of honor though in many clime whiteness typifies the majesty of justice in the ermine of the judge and contributes to the daily state of king and queen drawn by milk white steed though even in the higher mystery of the most august religion it ha been made the symbol of the divine spotlessness and power by the persian fire worshipper the white forked flame being held the holiest on the altar and in the greek mythology great jove himself being made incarnate in a snow white bull and though to the noble iroquois the midwinter sacrifice of the sacred white dog wa by far the holiest festival of their theology that spotless faithful creature being held the purest envoy they could send to the great spirit with the annual tidings of their own fidelity and though directly from the latin word for white all christian priest derive the name of one part of their sacred vesture the alb or tunic worn beneath the cassock and though among the holy pomp of the romish faith white is specially employed in the celebration of the passion of our lord though in the vision of st john white robe are given to the redeemed and the four and twenty elder stand clothed in white before the great white throne and the holy one that sitteth there white like wool yet for all these accumulated association with whatever is sweet and honorable and sublime there yet lurks an elusive something in the innermost idea of this hue which strike more of panic to the soul than that redness which affright in blood this elusive quality it is which cause the thought of whiteness when divorced from more kindly association and coupled with any object terrible in itself to heighten that terror to the furthest bound witness the white bear of the pole and the white shark of the tropic what but their smooth flaky whiteness make them the transcendent horror they are that ghastly whiteness it is which imparts such an abhorrent mildness even more loathsome than terrific to the dumb gloating of their aspect so that not the fierce fanged tiger in his heraldic coat can so stagger courage a the white shrouded bear or shark with reference to the polar bear it may possibly be urged by him who would fain go still deeper into this matter that it is not the whiteness separately regarded which heightens the intolerable hideousness of that brute for analysed that heightened hideousness it might be said only rise from the circumstance that the irresponsible ferociousness of the creature stand invested in the fleece of celestial innocence and love and hence by bringing together two such opposite emotion in our mind the polar bear frightens u with so unnatural a contrast but even assuming all this to be true yet were it not for the whiteness you would not have that intensified terror a for the white shark the white gliding ghostliness of repose in that creature when beheld in his ordinary mood strangely tally with the same quality in the polar quadruped this peculiarity is most vividly hit by the french in the captain ahab down into his cabin after the squall that took place on the night succeeding that wild ratification of his purpose with his crew you would have seen him go to a locker in the transom and bringing out a large wrinkled roll of yellowish sea chart spread them before him on his screwed down table then seating himself before it you would have seen him intently study the various line and shading which there met his eye and with slow but steady pencil trace additional course over space that before were blank at interval he would refer to pile of old log book beside him wherein were set down the season and place in which on various former voyage of various ship sperm whale had been captured or seen while thus employed the heavy pewter lamp suspended in chain over his head continually rocked with the motion of the ship and for ever threw shifting gleam and shadow of line upon his wrinkled brow till it almost seemed that while he himself wa marking out line and course on the wrinkled chart some invisible pencil wa also tracing line and course upon the deeply marked chart of his forehead but it wa not this night in particular that in the solitude of his cabin ahab thus pondered over his chart almost every night they were brought out almost every night some pencil mark were effaced and others were substituted for with the chart of all four ocean before him ahab wa threading a maze of current and eddy with a view to the more certain accomplishment of that monomaniac thought of his soul now to any one not fully acquainted with the way of the leviathan it might seem an absurdly hopeless task thus to seek out one solitary creature in the unhooped ocean of this planet but not so did it seem to ahab who knew the set of all tide and current and thereby calculating the drifting of the sperm whale s food and also calling to mind the regular ascertained season for hunting him in particular latitude could arrive at reasonable surmise almost approaching to certainty concerning the timeliest day to be upon this or that ground in search of his prey so assured indeed is the fact concerning the periodicalness of the sperm whale s resorting to given water that many hunter believe that could he be closely observed and studied throughout the world were the log for one voyage of the entire whale fleet carefully collated then the migration of the sperm whale would be found to correspond in invariability to those of the herring shoal or the flight of swallow on this hint attempt have been made to construct elaborate migratory chart of the sperm whale since the above wa written the statement is happily borne out by an official circular issued by lieutenant maury of the national observatory washington april th by that circular it appears that precisely such a chart is in course of completion and portion of it are presented in the circular this chart divide the ocean into district of five degree of latitude by five degree of longitude perpendicularly through each of which district are twelve column for the twelve month and horizontally through each of which district are three line one to show the number of day that have been spent in each month in every district and the two others to show the number of day in which whale sperm or right have been seen besides when making a passage from one feeding ground to another the sperm whale guided by some infallible instinct say rather secret intelligence from the deity mostly swim in vein a they are called continuing their way along a given ocean line with such undeviating exactitude that no ship ever sailed her course by any chart with one tithe of such marvellous precision though in these case the direction taken by any one whale be straight a a surveyor s parallel and though the line of advance be strictly confined to it own unavoidable straight wake yet the arbitrary vein in which at these time he is said to swim generally embrace some few mile in width more or less a the vein is presumed to expand or contract but never exceeds the visual sweep from the whale ship s mast head when circumspectly gliding along this magic zone the sum is that at particular season within that breadth and along that path migrating whale may with great confidence be looked for and hence not only at substantiated time upon well known separate feeding ground could ahab hope subordinate is the steersman upon the occasion and the captain having no place to sit in is pulled off to his visit all standing like a pine tree and often you will notice that being conscious of the eye of the whole visible world resting on him from the side of the two ship this standing captain is all alive to the importance of sustaining his dignity by maintaining his leg nor is this any very easy matter for in his rear is the immense projecting steering oar hitting him now and then in the small of his back the after oar reciprocating by rapping his knee in front he is thus completely wedged before and behind and can only expand himself sideways by settling down on his stretched leg but a sudden violent pitch of the boat will often go far to topple him because length of foundation understanding of all similar scene elsewhere presented i have here to speak of the magical sometimes horrible whale line the line originally used in the fishery wa of the best hemp slightly vapored sailor for common ship use yet not only would the ordinary quantity too much stiffen the whale line for the close coiling to which it must be subjected but a most seaman are beginning to learn tar in general by no mean add to the rope s durability or strength however much it may give it compactness and gloss of late year the manilla rope ha in the american fishery almost entirely superseded hemp a a material for whale line for though not so durable a hemp it is stronger and far more soft and elastic and i will add since there is an sthetics in all thing is much more handsome and becoming to the boat than hemp hemp is a dusky dark fellow a sort of indian but manilla is a a golden haired circassian to behold the whale line is only two third of an inch in thickness at first sight you would not think it so strong a it really is by experiment it one and fifty yarn will each suspend a weight of one hundred and twenty pound so that the whole rope will bear a strain nearly equal to three ton in length the common sperm whale line measure something over two hundred fathom towards the stern of the boat it is spirally coiled away in the tub not like the worm pipe of a still though but so a to form one round cheese shaped mass of densely bedded sheaf or layer of concentric spiralizations without any hollow but the heart or minute vertical tube formed at the axis of the cheese a the least an entire morning in this business carrying the line high aloft and then reeving it downwards through a block towards the tub so a in the act of coiling to free it from all possible wrinkle and twist in the english boat two tub are used instead of one the same line being continuously coiled in both tub there is some advantage in this because these twin tub being so small they fit more readily into the boat and do not strain it so much whereas the american tub nearly three foot in diameter and of proportionate depth make a rather bulky freight for a craft whose plank are but one half inch in thickness for the bottom of the whale boat is like critical ice which will bear up a considerable distributed weight but not very much of a concentrated one when the painted canvas cover is clapped on the american line tub the boat look a if it were pulling off with a prodigious great wedding cake to present to the whale both end of the line are exposed the lower end terminating in an eye splice or loop coming up from the bottom against the side of the tub and hanging over it edge completely disengaged from everything this arrangement of the lower end is necessary on two account first in order to facilitate the fastening to it of an additional line from a neighboring boat in case the stricken whale should sound so deep a to threaten to carry off the entire line originally attached to the harpoon in these instance the whale of course is shifted like a mug of ale a it were from the one boat to the other though the first boat always hovers at hand to assist it consort second this arrangement is indispensable for common safety s sake for were the lower end of the line in any way attached to the boat and were the whale then to run the line out to the end almost in a single smoking minute a he sometimes doe he would not stop there for the doomed boat would infallibly be dragged down after him into the profundity of the sea and in that case no town crier would ever find her again before lowering the boat for the chase the upper end of the line is taken aft from the tub and passing round the loggerhead there is again carried forward the entire length of the boat chapter the dart a word concerning an incident in the last chapter according to the invariable usage of the fishery the whale boat push off from the ship with the headsman or whale killer a temporary steersman and the harpooneer or whale fastener pulling the foremost oar the one known a the harpooneer oar now it need a strong nervous arm to strike the first iron into the fish for often in what is called a long dart the heavy implement ha to be flung to the distance of twenty or thirty foot but however prolonged and exhausting the chase the harpooneer is expected to pull his oar meanwhile to the uttermost indeed he is expected to set an example of superhuman activity to the rest not only by incredible rowing but by repeated loud and intrepid exclamation and what it is to keep shouting at the top of one s compass while all the other muscle are strained and half started what that is none know but those who have tried it for one i can not bawl very heartily and work very recklessly at one and the same time in this straining bawling state then with his back to the fish all at once the exhausted harpooneer hears the exciting cry stand up and give it to him he now ha to drop and secure his oar turn round on his centre half way seize his harpoon from the crotch and with what little strength may remain he essay to pitch it somehow into the whale no wonder taking the whole fleet of whalemen in a body that out of fifty fair chance for a dart not five are successful no wonder that so many hapless harpooneer are madly cursed and disrated no wonder that some of them actually burst their blood vessel in the boat no wonder that some sperm whalemen are absent four year with four barrel no wonder that to many ship owner whaling is but a losing concern for it is the harpooneer that make the voyage and if you take the breath out of his body how can you expect to find it there when most wanted again if the dart be successful then at the second critical instant that is when the whale start to run the boatheader and harpooneer likewise start to running fore and aft to the imminent jeopardy of themselves and every one else it is then they change place and the headsman the chief officer of the little craft take his proper station in the bow of the boat now i care not who maintains the contrary but all this is both foolish and unnecessary the headsman should stay in the bow from first to last he should both dart the harpoon and the lance and no rowing whatever should be expected of him except under circumstance obvious to any fisherman i know that this would sometimes involve a slight loss of speed in the chase but long experience in various whalemen of more than one nation ha convinced me that in the vast majority of failure in the fishery it ha not by any mean been so much the speed of the whale a the before described exhaustion of the harpooneer that ha caused them to insure the greatest efficiency in the dart the harpooneer of this world must start to their foot from out of idleness and not from out of toil chapter the crotch out of the trunk the branch grow out of them the twig so in productive subject grow the chapter the crotch alluded to on a previous page deserves independent mention it is a notched stick of a peculiar form some two foot in length which is perpendicularly inserted into the starboard gunwale near the bow for the purpose of furnishing a rest for the wooden extremity of the harpoon whose other naked barbed end slopingly project from the prow thereby the weapon is instantly at hand to it hurler who snatch it up a readily from it rest a a backwoodsman swing his rifle from the wall it is customary to have two harpoon reposing in the crotch respectively called the first and second iron but these two harpoon each by it own cord are both connected with the line the object being this to dart them both if possible one instantly after the other into the same whale so that if in the coming drag one should draw out the other may still retain a hold it is a doubling of the chance but it very often happens that owing to the instantaneous violent convulsive running of the whale upon receiving the first iron it becomes impossible for the harpooneer however lightning like in his movement to pitch the second iron into him nevertheless a the second iron is already connected with the line and the line is running hence that weapon must at all event be anticipatingly tossed out of the boat somehow and somewhere else the most terrible jeopardy would involve all hand tumbled into the water it accordingly is in such case the spare coil of box line mentioned in a preceding chapter making this feat in most instance prudently practicable but this critical act is not always unattended with the saddest and most fatal casualty furthermore you must know that when the second iron is thrown overboard it thenceforth becomes a dangling sharp edged terror skittishly curvetting about both boat and whale entangling the line or cutting them and making a prodigious sensation in all direction nor in general is it possible to secure it again until the whale is fairly captured and a corpse consider now how it must be in the case of four boat all engaging one unusually strong active and knowing whale when owing to these quality in him a well a to the thousand concurring accident of such an audacious enterprise eight or ten loose second iron may be simultaneously dangling about him for of course each boat is supplied with several harpoon to bend on to the line should the first one be ineffectually darted chapter the shark massacre when in the southern fishery a captured sperm whale after long and weary toil is brought alongside late at night it is not a a general thing at least customary to proceed at once to the business of cutting him in for that business is an exceedingly laborious one is not very soon completed and requires all hand to set about it therefore the common usage is to take in all sail lash the helm a lee and then send every one below to his hammock till daylight with the reservation that until that time anchor watch shall be kept that is two and two for an hour each couple the crew in rotation shall mount the deck to see that all go well but sometimes especially upon the line in the pacific this plan will not answer at all because such incalculable host of shark gather round the moored carcase that were he left so for six hour say on a stretch little more than the skeleton would be visible by morning in most other part of the ocean however where these fish do not so largely abound their wondrous voracity can be at time considerably diminished by vigorously stirring them up with sharp whaling spade a procedure notwithstanding which in some instance only seems to tickle them into still greater activity but it wa not thus in the present case with the pequod s shark though to be sure any man unaccustomed to such sight to have looked over her side that night would have almost thought the whole round sea wa one huge cheese and those shark the maggot in it nevertheless upon stubb setting the anchor watch after his supper wa concluded and when accordingly queequeg and a forecastle seaman came on deck no small excitement wa created among the shark for immediately suspending the cutting stage over the side and lowering three lantern so that they cast long gleam of light over the turbid sea these two mariner darting their long whaling spade kept up an incessant murdering of the shark by striking the keen steel deep into their skull seemingly their only vital part but in the foamy confusion of their mixed and struggling host the marksman could not always hit their mark and this brought about new revelation of the incredible ferocity of the foe they viciously snapped not only at each other s disembowelment but like flexible bow bent round and bit their own till those entrails seemed swallowed over and over again by the same mouth to be oppositely voided by the gaping wound nor wa this all it wa unsafe to meddle with the corps and ghost of these creature a sort of generic or pantheistic vitality seemed to lurk in their very joint and bone after what might be called the individual life had departed killed and hoisted on deck for the sake of his skin one of these shark almost took poor queequeg s hand off when he tried to shut down the dead lid of his murderous jaw the whaling spade used for cutting in is made of the very best steel is about the bigness of a man s spread hand and in general shape corresponds to the garden implement after which it is named only it side are perfectly flat and it upper end considerably narrower than the lower this weapon is always kept a sharp a possible and when being used is occasionally honed just like a razor in it socket a stiff pole from twenty to thirty foot long is inserted for a handle queequeg no care what god made him shark said the savage agonizingly lifting his hand up and down wedder fejee god or nantucket god but de god wat made shark must be one dam ingin chapter cutting in it wa a saturday night and such a sabbath a followed ex officio professor of sabbath breaking are all whalemen the ivory pequod wa turned into what seemed a shamble every sailor a butcher you would have thought we were offering up ten thousand red ox to the sea god in the first place the enormous cutting tackle among other ponderous thing comprising a cluster of block generally painted green and which no single man can possibly lift this vast bunch of grape wa swayed up to the main top and firmly lashed to the lower mast head the strongest point anywhere above a ship s deck the end of the hawser like rope winding through these intricacy wa then conducted to the windlass and the huge lower block of the tackle wa swung over the whale to this block the great blubber hook weighing some one hundred pound wa attached and now suspended in stage over the side starbuck and stubb the mate armed with their long spade began cutting a hole in the body for the insertion of the hook just above the nearest of the two side fin this done a broad semicircular line is cut round the hole the hook is inserted and the main body of the crew striking up a wild chorus now commence heaving in one dense crowd at the windlass when instantly the entire ship careen over on her side every bolt in her start like the nail head of an old house in frosty weather she tremble quiver and nod her frighted mast head to the sky more and more she lean over to the whale while every gasping heave of the windlass is answered by a helping heave from the billow till at last a swift startling snap is heard with a great swash the ship roll upwards and backwards from the whale and the triumphant tackle rise into sight dragging after it the disengaged semicircular end of the first strip of blubber now a the blubber envelope the whale precisely a the rind doe an orange so is it stripped off from the body precisely a an orange is sometimes stripped by spiralizing it for the strain constantly kept up by the windlass continually keep the whale rolling over and over in the water and a the blubber in one strip uniformly peel off along the line called the scarf simultaneously cut by the spade of starbuck and stubb the mate and just a fast a it is thus peeled off and indeed by that very act itself it is all the time being hoisted higher and higher aloft till it upper end graz the main top the men at the windlass then cease heaving and for a moment or two the prodigious blood dripping mass sway to and fro a if let down from the sky and every one present must take good heed to dodge it when it swing else it may box his ear and pitch him headlong overboard one of the attending harpooneer now advance with a long keen weapon called a boarding sword and watching his chance he dexterously slice out a considerable hole in the lower part of the swaying mass into this hole the end of the second alternating great tackle is then hooked so a to retain a hold upon the blubber in order to prepare for what follows whereupon this accomplished swordsman warning all hand to stand off once more make a scientific dash at the mass and with a few sidelong desperate lunging slicing severs it completely in twain so that while the short lower part is still fast the long upper strip called a blanket piece swing clear and is all ready for lowering the heaver forward now resume their song and while the one tackle is peeling and hoisting a second strip from the whale the other is slowly slackened away and down go the first strip through the main hatchway right beneath into an unfurnished parlor called the blubber room into this twilight apartment sundry nimble hand keep coiling away the long blanket piece a if it were a great live mass of plaited serpent and thus the work proceeds the two tackle hoisting and lowering simultaneously both whale and windlass heaving the heaver singing the blubber room gentleman coiling the mate scarfing the ship straining and all hand swearing occasionally by way of assuaging the general friction chapter the blanket i have given no small attention to that not unvexed subject the skin of the whale i have had controversy about it with experienced whalemen afloat and learned naturalist ashore my original opinion remains unchanged but it is only an opinion the question is what and where is the skin of the whale already you know what his blubber is that blubber is something of the consistence of firm close grained beef but tougher more elastic and compact and range from eight or ten to twelve and fifteen inch in thickness now however preposterous it may at first seem to talk of any creature s skin a being of that sort of consistence and thickness yet in point of fact these are no argument against such a presumption because you can not raise any other dense enveloping layer from the whale s body but that same blubber and the outermost enveloping layer of any animal if reasonably dense what can that be but the skin true from the unmarred dead body of the whale you may scrape off with your hand an infinitely thin transparent substance somewhat resembling the thinnest shred of isinglass only it is almost a flexible and soft a satin that is previous to being dried when it not only contract and thickens but becomes rather hard and brittle i have several such dried bit which i use for mark in my whale book it is transparent a i said before and being laid upon the printed page i have sometimes pleased myself with fancying it exerted a magnifying influence at any rate it is pleasant to read about whale through their own spectacle a you may say but what i am driving at here is this that same infinitely thin isinglass substance which i admit invests the entire body of the whale is not so much to be regarded a the skin of the creature a the skin of the skin so to speak for it were simply ridiculous to say that the proper skin of the tremendous whale is thinner and more tender than the skin of a new born child but no more of this assuming the blubber to be the skin of the whale then when this skin a in the case of a very large sperm whale will yield the bulk of one hundred barrel of oil and when it is considered that in quantity or rather weight that oil in it expressed state is only three fourth and not the entire substance of the coat some idea may hence be had of the enormousness of that animated mass a mere part of whose mere integument yield such a lake of liquid a that reckoning ten barrel to the ton you have ten ton for the net weight of only three quarter of the stuff of the whale s skin in life the visible surface of the sperm whale is not the least among the many marvel he present almost invariably it is all over obliquely crossed and re crossed with numberless straight mark in thick array something like those in the finest italian line engraving but these mark do not seem to be impressed upon the isinglass substance above mentioned but seem to be seen through it a if they were engraved upon the body itself nor is this all in some instance to the quick observant eye those linear mark a in a veritable engraving but afford the ground for far other delineation these are hieroglyphical that is if you call those mysterious cypher on the wall of pyramid hieroglyphic then that is the proper word to use in the present connexion by my retentive memory of the hieroglyphic upon one sperm whale in particular i wa much struck with a plate representing the old indian character chiselled on the famous hieroglyphic palisade on the bank of the upper mississippi like those mystic rock too the mystic marked whale remains undecipherable this allusion to the indian rock reminds me of another thing besides all the other phenomenon which the exterior of the sperm whale present he not seldom display the back and more especially his flank effaced in great part of the regular linear appearance by reason of numerous rude scratch altogether of an irregular random aspect i should say that those new england rock on the sea coast which agassiz imago to bear the mark of violent scraping contact with vast floating iceberg i should say that those rock must not a little resemble the sperm whale in this particular it also seems to me that such scratch in the whale are probably made by hostile contact with other whale for i have most remarked them in the large full grown bull of the specie a word or two more concerning this matter of the skin or blubber of the whale it ha already been said that it is stript from him in long piece called blanket piece like most sea term this one is very happy and significant for the whale is indeed wrapt up in his blubber a in a real blanket or counterpane or still better an indian poncho slipt over his head and skirting his extremity it is by reason of this cosy blanketing of his body that the whale is enabled to keep himself comfortable in all weather in all sea time and tide what would become of a greenland whale say in those shuddering icy sea of the north if unsupplied with his cosy surtout true other fish are found exceedingly brisk in those hyperborean water but these be it observed are your cold blooded lungless fish whose very belly are refrigerator creature that warm water where when seaman fall overboard they are sometimes found month afterwards perpendicularly frozen into the heart of field of ice a a fly is found glued in amber but more surprising is it to know a ha been proved by experiment that the blood of a polar whale is warmer than that of a borneo negro in summer it doe seem to me that herein we see the rare virtue of a strong individual vitality and that previous to completely stripping the body of the leviathan he wa beheaded now the beheading of the sperm whale is a scientific anatomical feat upon which experienced whale surgeon very much pride themselves and not without reason consider that the whale ha nothing that can properly be called a neck on the contrary where his head and body seem to join there in that very place is the thickest part of him remember also that the surgeon must operate from above some eight or ten foot intervening between him and his subject and that subject almost hidden in a discoloured rolling and oftentimes tumultuous and bursting sea bear in mind too that under these untoward circumstance he ha to cut many foot deep in the flesh and in that subterraneous manner without so much a getting one single peep into the ever contracting gash thus made he must skilfully steer clear of all adjacent interdicted part and exactly divide the spine at a critical point hard by it insertion into the skull do you not marvel then at stubb s boast that he demanded but ten minute to behead a sperm whale when first severed the head is dropped astern and held there by a cable till the body is stripped that done if it belong to a small whale it is hoisted on deck to be deliberately disposed of but with a full grown leviathan this is impossible for the sperm whale s head embrace nearly one third of his entire bulk and completely to suspend such a burden a that even by the immense tackle of a whaler this were a vain a thing a to attempt weighing a dutch barn in jeweller scale the pequod s whale being decapitated and the body stripped the head wa hoisted against the ship s side about half way out of the sea so that it might yet in great part be buoyed up by it native element and there with the strained craft steeply leaning over to it by reason of the enormous downward drag from the lower mast head and every yard arm on that side projecting like a crane over the wave there that blood dripping head hung to leviathan the sperm whale and the right whale are by far the most noteworthy they are the only whale regularly hunted by man to the nantucketer they present the two extreme of all the known variety of the whale a the external difference between them is mainly observable in their head and a a head of each is this moment hanging from the pequod s side and a we may freely go from one to the other by merely stepping across the deck where i should like to know will you obtain a better chance to study practical cetology than here in the first place you are struck by the general contrast between these head both are massive enough in all conscience but there is a certain mathematical symmetry in the sperm whale s which the right whale s sadly lack there is more character in the sperm whale s head a you behold it you involuntarily yield the immense superiority to him in point of pervading dignity in the present instance too this dignity is heightened by the pepper and salt colour of his head at the summit giving token of advanced age and large experience in short he is what the fisherman technically call a grey headed whale let u now note what is least dissimilar in these head namely the two most important organ the eye and the ear far back on the side of the head and low down near the angle of either whale s jaw if you narrowly search you will at last see a lashless eye which you would fancy to be a young colt s eye so out of all proportion is it to the magnitude of the head now from this peculiar sideway position of the whale s eye it is plain that he can never see an object which is exactly ahead no more than he can one exactly astern in a word the position of the whale s eye corresponds to that of a man s ear and you may fancy for yourself how it would fare with you did you sideways survey object through your ear you would find that you could only command some thirty degree of vision in advance of the straight side line of sight and about thirty more behind it if your bitterest foe were walking straight towards you with dagger uplifted in broad day you would not be able to see him any more than if he were stealing upon you from behind in a word you would have two back so to speak but at the same time also two front side front for what is it that make the front of a man what indeed but his eye moreover while in most other animal that i can now think of the eye are so planted a imperceptibly to blend their visual power so a to produce one picture and not two to the brain the peculiar position of the whale s eye effectually divided a they are by many cubic foot of solid head which tower between them like a great mountain separating two lake in valley this of course must wholly separate the impression which each independent organ imparts the whale undecreasing girth almost equal to that of the brain under all these circumstance would it be unreasonable to survey and map out the whale s spine phrenologically for viewed in this light the wonderful comparative smallness of his brain proper is more than compensated by the wonderful comparative magnitude of his spinal cord but leaving this hint to operate a it may with the phrenologist i the long and narrow peninsula of malacca extending south eastward from the territory of birmah form the most southerly point of all asia in a continuous line from that peninsula stretch the long island of sumatra java bally and timor which with many others form a vast mole or rampart lengthwise connecting asia with australia and dividing the long unbroken indian ocean from the thickly studded oriental archipelago this rampart is pierced by several sally port for the convenience of ship and whale conspicuous among which are the strait of sunda and malacca by the strait of sunda chiefly vessel bound to china from the west emerge into the china sea those narrow strait of sunda divide sumatra from java and standing midway in that vast rampart of island buttressed by that bold green appearance however ineffectual of being guarded from the all grasping western world the shore of the strait of sunda are unsupplied with those domineering fortress which guard the entrance to the mediterranean the baltic and the propontis unlike the dane these oriental do not demand the obsequious homage of lowered top sail from the endless procession of ship before the wind which for century loose fish the allusion to the waif and waif pole in the last chapter but one necessitates some account of the law and regulation of the whale fishery of which the waif may be deemed the grand symbol and badge it frequently happens that when several ship are cruising in company a whale may be struck by one vessel then escape and be finally killed and captured by another vessel and herein are indirectly comprised many minor contingency all partaking of this one grand feature for example after a weary and perilous chase and capture of a whale the body may get loose from the ship by reason of a violent storm and drifting far away to leeward be retaken by a second whaler who in a calm snugly tow it alongside without risk of life or line thus the most vexatious and violent dispute would often arise between the fisherman were there not some written or unwritten universal undisputed law applicable to all case perhaps the only formal whaling code authorized by legislative enactment wa that of holland it wa decreed by the state general in a d but though no other nation ha ever had any written whaling law yet the american fisherman have been their own legislator and lawyer in this matter they have provided a system which for terse comprehensiveness surpasses justinian s pandects and the by law of the chinese society for the suppression of meddling with other people s business yes these law might be engraven on a queen anne s farthing or the barb of a harpoon and worn round the neck so small are they i a fast fish belongs to the party fast to it ii a loose fish is fair game for anybody who can soonest catch it but what play the mischief with this masterly code is the admirable brevity of it which necessitates a vast volume of commentary to expound it first what is a fast fish alive or dead a fish is technically fast when it is connected with an occupied ship or boat by any medium at all controllable by the occupant or occupant a mast an oar a nine inch cable a telegraph wire or a strand of cobweb it is all the same likewise a fish is technically fast when it bear a waif or any other recognised symbol of possession so long a the party waifing it plainly evince their ability at any time to take it alongside a well a their intention so to do these are scientific commentary but the commentary of the whalemen themselves sometimes consist in hard word and harder knock the coke upon littleton of the fist true among the more upright and honorable whalemen allowance are always made for peculiar case where it would be an outrageous moral injustice for one party to claim possession of a whale previously chased or killed by another party but others are by no mean so scrupulous some fifty year ago there wa a curious case of whale trover litigated in england wherein the plaintiff set forth that after a hard chase of a whale in the northern sea and when indeed they the plaintiff had succeeded in harpooning the fish they were at last through peril of their life obliged to forsake not only their line but their boat itself ultimately the defendant the crew of another ship came up with the whale struck killed seized and finally appropriated it before the very eye of the plaintiff and when those defendant were remonstrated with their captain snapped his finger in the plaintiff teeth and assured them that by way of doxology to the deed he had done he would now retain their line harpoon and boat which had remained attached to the whale at the time of the seizure wherefore the plaintiff now sued for the recovery of the value of their whale line harpoon and boat mr erskine wa counsel for the defendant lord ellenborough wa the judge in the course of the defence the witty erskine went on to illustrate his position by alluding to a recent crim con case wherein a gentleman after in vain trying to bridle his wife s viciousness had at last abandoned her upon the sea of life but in the course of year repenting of that step he instituted an action to recover possession of her erskine wa on the other side and he then supported it by saying that though the gentleman had originally harpooned the lady and had once had her fast and only by reason of the great stress of her plunging viciousness had at last abandoned her yet abandon her he did so that she became a loose fish and therefore when a subsequent gentleman re harpooned her the lady then became that subsequent gentleman s property along with whatever harpoon might have been found sticking in her now in the present case erskine contended that the example of the whale and the lady were reciprocally illustrative of each other these pleading and the counter pleading being duly heard the very learned judge in set term decided to wit that a for the boat he awarded it to the plaintiff because they had merely abandoned it to save their life but that with regard to the controverted whale harpoon and line they belonged to the defendant the whale because it wa a loose fish at the time of the final capture and the harpoon and line because when the fish made off with them it the fish acquired a property in those article and hence anybody who afterwards took the fish had a right to them now the defendant afterwards took the fish ergo the aforesaid article were theirs a common man looking at this decision of the very learned judge might possibly object to it but ploughed up to the primary rock of the matter the two great principle laid down in the twin whaling law previously quoted and applied and elucidated by lord ellenborough in the above cited case these two law touching fast fish and loose fish i say will on reflection be found the fundamental of all human jurisprudence for notwithstanding it complicated tracery of sculpture the temple of the law like the temple of the philistine ha but two prop to stand on is it not a saying in every one s mouth possession is half of the law that is regardless of how the thing came into possession but often possession is the whole of the law what are the sinew and soul of russian serf and republican slave but fast fish whereof possession is the whole of the law what to the rapacious landlord is the widow s last mite but a fast fish what is yonder undetected villain s marble mansion with a door plate for a waif what is that but a fast fish what is the ruinous discount which mordecai the broker get from poor woebegone the bankrupt on a loan to keep woebegone s family from starvation what is that ruinous discount but a fast fish what is the archbishop of savesoul s income of seized from the scant bread and cheese of hundred of thousand of broken backed laborer all sure of heaven without any of savesoul s help what is that globular but a fast fish what are the duke of dunder s hereditary town and hamlet but fast fish what to that redoubted harpooneer john bull is poor ireland but a fast fish what to that apostolic lancer brother jonathan is texas but a fast fish and concerning all these is not possession the whole of the law but if the doctrine of fast fish be pretty generally applicable the kindred doctrine of loose fish is still more widely so that is internationally and universally applicable what wa america in but a loose fish in which columbus struck the spanish standard by way of waifing it for his royal master and mistress what wa poland to the czar what greece to the turk what india to england what at last will mexico be to the united state all loose fish what are the right of man and the liberty of the world but loose fish what all men s mind and opinion but loose fish what is the principle of religious belief in them but a loose fish what to the ostentatious smuggling verbalists are the thought of thinker but loose fish what is the great globe itself but a loose fish and what are you reader but a loose fish and a fast fish too chapter head or tail de balena vero sufficit si rex habeat caput et regina caudam bracton l c latin from the book of the law of itself a problem to the learned though the word ambergris is but the french compound for grey amber yet the two substance are quite distinct for amber though at time found on the sea coast is also dug up in some far inland soil whereas ambergris is never found except upon the sea besides amber is a hard transparent brittle odorless substance used for mouth piece to pipe for bead and ornament but ambergris is soft waxy and so highly fragrant and spicy that it is largely used in perfumery in pastiles precious candle hair powder and pomatum the turk use it in cooking and also carry it to mecca for the same purpose that frankincense is carried to st peter s in rome some wine merchant drop a few grain into claret to flavor it who would think then that such fine lady and gentleman should regale themselves with an essence found in the inglorious bowel of a sick whale yet so it is by some ambergris is supposed to be the cause and by others the effect of the dyspepsia in the whale how to cure such a dyspepsia it were hard to say unless by administering three or four boat load of brandreth s pill and then running out of harm s way a laborer do in blasting rock i have forgotten to say it in quality chapter the try work besides her hoisted boat an american whaler is outwardly distinguished by her try work she present the curious anomaly of the most solid masonry joining with oak and hemp in constituting the completed ship it is a if from the open field a brick kiln were transported to her plank the try work are planted between the foremast and mainmast the most roomy part of the deck the timber beneath are of a peculiar strength fitted to sustain the weight of an almost solid mass of brick and mortar some ten foot by eight square and five in height the foundation doe not penetrate the deck but the masonry is firmly secured to the surface by ponderous knee of iron bracing it on all side and screwing it down to the timber on the flank it is cased with wood and at top completely covered by a large sloping battened hatchway removing this hatch we expose the great try pot two in number and each of several barrel capacity when not in use they are kept remarkably clean sometimes they are polished with soapstone and sand till they shine within like silver punch bowl during the night watch some cynical old sailor will crawl into them and coil themselves away there for a nap while employed in polishing them one man in each pot side by side many confidential communication are carried on over the iron lip it is a place also for profound mathematical meditation it wa freshet rushing carpet for ever slide away the weaver god he weave and by that weaving is he deafened that he hears no mortal voice and by that humming we too who look on the loom are deafened and only when we escape it shall we hear the thousand voice that speak through it for even so it is in all material factory the spoken word that are inaudible among the flying spindle those same word are plainly heard without the wall bursting from the opened casement thereby have villainy been detected ah mortal then be heedful for so in all this din of the great world s loom thy subtlest thinking
