whale chapter measurement of the whale s skeleton in the first place i wish to lay before you a particular plain statement touching the living bulk of this leviathan whose skeleton we are briefly to exhibit such a statement may prove useful here according to a careful calculation i have made and which i partly base upon captain scoresby s estimate of seventy ton for the largest sized greenland whale of sixty foot in length according to my careful calculation i say a sperm whale of the largest magnitude between eighty five and ninety foot in length and something less than forty foot in it fullest circumference such a whale will weigh at least ninety ton so that reckoning thirteen men to a ton he would considerably outweigh the combined population of a whole village of one thousand one hundred inhabitant think you not then that brain like yoked cattle should be put to this leviathan to make him at all budge to any landsman s imagination having already in various way put before you his skull spout hole jaw teeth tail forehead fin and diver other part i shall now simply point out what is most interesting in the general bulk of his unobstructed bone but a the colossal skull embrace so very large a proportion of the entire extent of the skeleton a it is by far the most complicated part and a nothing is to be repeated concerning it in this chapter you must not fail to carry it in your mind or under your arm a we proceed otherwise you will not gain a complete notion of the general structure we are about to view in length the sperm whale s skeleton at tranque measured seventy two foot so that when fully invested and extended in life he must have been ninety foot long for in the whale the skeleton loses about one fifth in length compared with the living body of this seventy two foot his skull and jaw comprised some twenty foot leaving some fifty foot of plain back bone attached to this back bone for something less than a third of it length wa the mighty circular basket of rib which once enclosed his vitals to me this vast ivory ribbed chest with the long unrelieved spine extending far away from it in a straight line not a little resembled the hull of a great ship new laid upon the stock when only some twenty of her naked bow rib are inserted and the keel is otherwise for the time but a long disconnected timber the rib were ten on a side the first to begin from the neck wa nearly six foot long the second third and fourth were each successively longer till you came to the climax of the fifth or one of the middle rib which measured eight foot and some inch from that part the remaining rib diminished till the tenth and last only spanned five foot and some inch in general thickness they all bore a seemly correspondence to their length the middle rib were the most arched in some of the arsacides they are used for beam whereon to lay footpath bridge over small stream in considering these rib i could not but be struck anew with the circumstance so variously repeated in this book that the skeleton of the whale is by no mean the mould of his invested form the largest of the tranque rib one of the middle one occupied that part of the fish which in life is greatest in depth now the greatest depth of the invested body of this particular whale must have been at least sixteen foot whereas the corresponding rib measured but little more than eight foot so that this rib only conveyed half of the true notion of the living magnitude of that part besides for some way where i now saw but a naked spine all that had been once wrapped round with ton of added bulk in flesh muscle blood and bowel still more for the ample fin i here saw but a few disordered joint and in place of the weighty and majestic but boneless fluke an utter blank how vain and foolish then thought i for timid untravelled man to try to comprehend aright this wondrous whale by merely poring over his dead attenuated skeleton stretched in this peaceful wood no only in the heart of quickest peril only when within the eddyings of his angry fluke only on the profound unbounded sea can the fully invested whale be truly and livingly found out but the spine for that the best way we can consider it is with a crane to pile it bone high up on end no speedy enterprise but now it s done it look much like pompey s pillar there are forty and odd vertebr in all which in the skeleton are not locked together they mostly lie like the great knobbed block on a gothic spire forming solid course of heavy masonry the largest a middle one is in width something less than three foot and in depth more than four the smallest where the spine taper away into the tail is only two inch in width and look something like a white billiard ball i wa told that there were still smaller one but they had been lost by some little cannibal urchin the priest s child who had stolen them to play marble with thus we see how that the spine of even the hugest of living thing taper off at last into simple child s play chapter the fossil whale from his mighty bulk the whale affords a most congenial theme whereon to enlarge amplify and generally expatiate would you you could not compress him by good right he should only be treated of in imperial folio not to tell over again his furlong from spiracle to tail and the yard he measure about the waist only think of the gigantic involution of his intestine where they lie in him like great cable and hawser coiled away in the subterranean orlop deck of a line of battle ship since i have undertaken to manhandle this leviathan it behooves me to approve myself omnisciently exhaustive in the enterprise not overlooking the minutest seminal germ of his blood and spinning him out to the uttermost coil of his bowel having already described him in most of his present habitatory and anatomical peculiarity it now remains to magnify him in an arch ological fossiliferous and antediluvian point of view applied to any other creature than the leviathan to an ant or a flea such portly term might justly be deemed unwarrantably grandiloquent but when leviathan is the text the case is altered fain am i to stagger to this emprise under the weightiest word of the dictionary and here be it said that whenever it ha been convenient to consult one in the course of these dissertation i have invariably used a huge quarto edition of johnson expressly purchased for that purpose because that famous lexicographer s uncommon personal bulk more fitted him to compile a lexicon to be used by a whale author like me one often attached to it for they were slack because some play to the tiller wa indispensable in a severe gale like this while the ship is but a tossed shuttlecock to the blast it is by no mean uncommon to see the needle in the compass at interval go round and round it wa thus with the pequod s at almost every shock the helmsman had not failed to notice the whirling velocity with which they revolved upon the card it is a sight that hardly anyone can behold without some sort of unwonted emotion some hour after midnight the typhoon abated so much that through the strenuous exertion of starbuck and stubb be it said that this pertinacious pursuit of one particular whale continued through day into night and through night into day is a thing by no mean unprecedented in the south sea fishery for such is the wonderful skill prescience of experience and invincible confidence acquired by some great natural genius among the nantucket commander that from the simple observation of a whale when last descried they will under certain given circumstance pretty accurately foretell both the direction in which he will continue to swim for a time while out of sight a well a his probable rate of progression during that period and in these case somewhat a a pilot when about losing sight of a coast whose general trending he well know and which he desire shortly to return to again but at some further point like a this pilot stand by his compass and take the precise bearing of the cape at present visible in order the more certainly to hit aright the remote unseen headland eventually to be visited so doe the fisherman at his compass with the whale for after being chased and diligently marked through several hour of daylight then when night obscures the fish the creature s future wake through the darkness is almost a established to the sagacious mind of the hunter a the pilot s coast is to him so that to this hunter s wondrous skill the proverbial evanescence of a thing writ in water a wake is to all desired purpose well nigh a reliable a the steadfast land and a the mighty iron leviathan of the modern railway is so familiarly known in it every pace that with watch in their hand men time his rate a doctor that of a baby s pulse and lightly say of it the up train or the down train will reach such or such a spot at such or such an hour even so almost there are occasion when these nantucketers time that other leviathan of the deep according to the observed humor of his speed and say to themselves so many hour hence this whale will have gone two hundred mile will have about reached this or that degree of latitude or longitude but to render this acuteness at all successful in the end the wind and the sea must be the whaleman s ally for of what present avail to the becalmed or windbound mariner is the skill that assures him he is exactly ninety three league and a quarter from his port inferable from these statement are many collateral subtile matter touching the
